title: 107_s2710
content: The Act is titled the "Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002." It introduces a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002 introduces a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The credit is determined based on the amount paid by the taxpayer during the taxable year for qualified employee health insurance expenses, with the applicable percentage varying based on the number of qualified employees and their average annual rate of wages. The credit is determined based on the average annual rate of wages of qualified employees, with varying percentages based on the number of employees and their wages. The Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002 introduces a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The credit is determined based on the average annual rate of wages of qualified employees, with varying percentages based on the number of employees and their wages. If the average annual rate of wages exceeds $10,000, a formula is used to calculate the applicable percentage for the employer. If the employer has not more than 50 qualified employees with an average annual rate of wages not exceeding $30,000, the applicable percentage shall not be less than 5 percent. The credit is determined based on the average annual rate of wages of qualified employees, with varying percentages based on the number of employees and their wages. The amount of qualified employee health insurance expenses taken into account for any qualified employee for any taxable year shall not exceed $2,000 for self-only coverage and $5,000 for family coverage. The Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002 introduces a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. An employer is considered as described in subsection (b) if they employed an average number of employees in the preceding calendar years. The determination is based on the average number of employees expected to be employed in the current calendar year. The term 'qualified employee health insurance expenses' is defined. The Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002 introduces a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Qualified employee health insurance expenses are defined as amounts paid by an employer for health insurance coverage provided to at least 50% of qualified employees. A qualified employee is defined as an employee who normally works more than 30 hours. The term 'qualified employee' refers to an employee who works more than 30 hours per week for the employer, excluding those eligible for certain health plans or benefits under specific programs or chapters of the Social Security Act. The term 'employee' excludes certain individuals but includes leased employees. 'Wages' are defined as per section 3121(a). Rules similar to section 52 apply. No double benefits allowed for deductions or credits. The section discusses the application of rules similar to section 52 for employee health insurance expenses. It also states that no double benefit will be allowed for deductions or credits. Additionally, it amends section 38(b) to include the employee health insurance expenses credit and specifies that the credit cannot be carried back before the effective date. The unused business credit for any taxable year related to the employee health insurance expenses credit cannot be carried back before January 1, 2003. A clerical amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this section apply to small business employee health insurance expenses incurred after December 31, 2002, for coverage established after the enactment of this Act.
